awd_titl_txt: RUI:   Affine Flags, p-adic Representations, and Quantum Cohomology
awd_abstract_narration:
This research project addresses problems in algebraic geometry, which studies solutions to systems of polynomial equations, and in representation theory, which aims to explain the basic building blocks of symmetry in mathematics and natural science. The central objects of study in this project are groups of invertible matrices with power series entries. Such algebraic groups over local fields have an especially beautiful decomposition into cells indexed by elements of a group of transformations that is generated by reflections across hyperplanes in Euclidean space. This cell decomposition permits an approach to understanding the algebraic geometry and representation theory of the matrix group by employing combinatorial and geometric techniques that exploit the abundant symmetry featured in the arrangement of the reflecting hyperplanes. The project also provides involves undergraduate students in mathematical research through summer research programs, year-long thesis projects, and participation in local colloquia, regional seminars, and national conferences.

The investigator will utilize and extend surprising relationships among p-adic representation theory, affine flag varieties in positive characteristic, the quantum cohomology of complex Grassmannians, and the homology of the affine Grassmannian. Concrete goals of the research include explicit type-free formulas for dimensions of affine Deligne-Lusztig varieties, values of p-adic orbital integrals, and products of quantum and affine Schubert classes. The primary tool in most projects is the alcove walk model for the affine flag variety, a uniform combinatorial platform that connects the study of affine Hecke algebras, crystal bases, Mirkovic-Vilonen cycles, quantum and affine Schubert calculus, and geodesics in the building of Kac-Moody groups.

por.por_cntn:
This research agenda consisted of a series of projects concerning geometric problems in algebraic groups over local fields, which are large collections of matrices, having power series entries rather than numerical ones. The critical focus was on certain subvarieties of the affine flag variety, which utilized interactions between various combinatorial decompositions indexed by transformations in Euclidean spaces of very high dimension, such as into affine Schubert cells. This approach exploited the underlying symmetry of the patterns of reflecting hyperplanes in these Euclidean spaces, which gave rise to many combinatorial formulations encoding topological data about the primary subvarieties of interest. 

The broad mathematical aim of this research project was to deepen and extend surprising relationships among affine flag varieties, the quantum cohomology of finite flag varieties, and the homology of the affine Grassmannian. The methods pioneered new interactions among (arithmetic) algebraic geometry, representation theory, geometric group theory, and algebraic combinatorics. Although the applications obtained are wide-reaching, our solutions represent a unification of the language in many separate subfields of mathematics and physics. The overarching philosophy was either to exchange infinite problems for finite ones, or vice versa, to implement an existing solution to an infinite problem to attack a finite one. Concrete project goals included explicit computations of non-emptiness patterns and dimensions of affine Deligne-Lusztig varieties, as well as products of quantum and affine Schubert classes. 

Problems in the affine flag variety were solved by exchanging unwieldy infinite formulations for computable finite data. Toward the study of affine Deligne-Lusztig varieties in the affine flag variety, we developed a general algorithm for detecting non-emptiness and calculating dimensions, by establishing the foundations of folded galleries with respect to chimneys in the requisite tessellated Euclidean space. Constructive proofs for non-emptiness and dimension formulas were obtained for large families of affine Deligne-Lusztig varieties, in addition to recursive formulas for describing shadows with respect to chimneys. Using substantially different methods, we proved a closed combinatorial formula for the maximal element in the partially ordered set of Newton points associated to an affine Schubert cell, expressed as the weight of a fixed path in a finite directed graph. Further, we identified the family of cordial elements, for which this poset of Newton points is especially well-behaved, with important geometric consequences such as equidimensionality and precise closure relations for the associated Newton stratum.

The results obtained concerning quantum cohomology were heavily inspired by Peterson's work relating this finite ring to the homology of the affine Grassmannian, which is infinite. In the case of the Grassmannian of m-planes in complex n-space, we explained the precise relationship between the Peterson comparison formula and two quantum-to-affine correspondences on the k-Schur functions representing the homology of the affine Grassmannian. We also provided a detailed account of the parabolic Peterson isomorphism, by giving a computable description of the requisite affine quotient and an explicit combinatorial correspondence between certain non-commutative k-Schur functions and the quantum Schubert basis. In the setting which additionally tracks the symmetry induced by the action of an algebraic torus, we proved an equivariant generalization of the rim hook rule, as well as a convenient equivariant quantum Pieri rule formulated in terms of cylindric skew shapes. We also established a surprising equivalence between the minimal monomial occurring in the product of two quantum Schubert classes in the complete flag variety and maximal elements of the Newton poset on the affine side.

The methods of this project permitted deep involvement by undergraduate students, several of which have even resulted in coauthored research articles. Students engaged directly in a variety of capacities: through year-long senior thesis work, summer research experiences, as well as funded post-graduate work. This research also contributed to promoting women in mathematics, especially through helping aspiring female mathematicians to make meaningful professional connections. In particular, the PI has contributed toward a variety of workshops with all-female participation, conferences with all-female organizing committees, and seminars with a commitment to inviting majority female speakers. As such, this project has directly fostered intellectual engagement for students and professional development for women in mathematics.
